ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about the relationship between NYC and Jewish leaders and movements. I had no idea how much I didn't know about the subject, and I am happy to say that I am now able to actually contribute to discussions about extremely significant topics such as immigration, public housing, and urban community dynamics because of this course.

--learned about the history of Jews in NYC, particularly focusing on the ways and places they lived
--practiced opening my mind to understanding perspectives from historical authors, encouraged me to think critically about my own identity

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great readings and great discussions 
Only improvement: maybe more visual media would help with grasping certain concepts

The strength of the class was that we had excellent readings to discuss.
To improve the class, sometimes there was too much volume of reading and I wasn't quite sure what to the away from it. This didn't work out well if our discussion was rambling and we didn't get to cover all of the material from the readings. To improve this, it might be nice to get a preview of the reading, for example questions to consider about each reading, to help digest them as we are reading at home. Another way to improve this would be to ask each of the discussion leaders to meet with you about their presentations before they present to make sure they cover all the important points.

The small class environment was conducive to good and animated conversations. One area for improvement is that over the course of the semester we never really got feedback on the smaller assignments we completed. It was a bit disappointing to never get feedback on our reading responses or presentations.

The class has a lot going for it. The readings are really interesting and well selected. The focus on housing gave an interesting window into the history of Jewish New York. The students really made the class, and discussion was lively and free flowing. But there was something lacking in the organization of the course and the discussions that kept it from being truly excellent. Even though we went pretty chronologically it still felt like we were skipping around. Even when we were discussing the readings it felt like we were poking in our favorite parts to try and find a point instead of being a little more guided through.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone seeking greater exposure to NYC history through the lens of public and private housing initiatives and physical space.
I would recommend this course because the we learned a lot of eye-opening history about how race, religion, housing, and government.

extras.title: JDST 425 01 - Jewish Space & Ethnicity in NY
